senses.de: To draw or pull towards oneself with physical force or by arousing interest or desire
senses.ex: The billboard was designed to attract attention.

Tips.title: Visual Imagery
Tips.description: Use 'attract' when describing something that catches the eye or stands out visually.
Tips.example: The vibrant colors of the painting attract many visitors.

Tips.title: Emotional Pull
Tips.description: 'Attract' can suggest a powerful emotional effect that draws people in.
Tips.example: The suspense in the story attracts a wide readership.

senses.de: To make someone like or be interested in something or someone
senses.ex: The museum attracts thousands of visitors every year.

Tips.title: Positive Quality
Tips.description: Implies someone or something has appealing qualities that encourage interest.
Tips.example: The hotel's friendly service attracts repeat customers.

Tips.title: Wide Appeal
Tips.description: 'Attract' often indicates a broad or significant level of interest from many people.
Tips.example: Her new book attracted critical acclaim.

senses.de: In physics, to pull towards without touching, as by the property of mass or charge

Tips.title: Invisible Forces
Tips.description: In physics, 'attract' means an unseen force is at work, pulling objects together.
Tips.example: Opposite electric charges attract each other.

Tips.title: Scientific Precision
Tips.description: When used in physics, 'attract' is a precise term with specific scientific meaning.
Tips.example: The Earth's gravity attracts nearby objects.

senses.de: To interact with someone or something in a way that makes them come closer or become involved
senses.ex: Her outgoing personality attracts a lot of friends.

Tips.title: Personal Qualities
Tips.description: Use 'attract' to talk about how a person's character traits can draw others to them.
Tips.example: His sense of humor attracts a wide circle of friends.

Tips.title: Relationship Building
Tips.description: Describes the ability to pull people together to form relationships or communities.
Tips.example: A shared interest in music attracted them to each other.

Allure.wordDefinition:
Allure refers to a quality that is captivating or tempting, while attract refers to the ability to draw attention or interest.

Allure refers to something that is irresistible or enchanting, while attract refers to something that catches your eye or curiosity.

For example, a luxurious perfume might have an allure that makes people want to wear it even if they don't need it, while a bright and colorful sign might attract people to visit a store or restaurant.

Overall, both words relate to the ability to captivate, but allure has a bit more of a magical or seductive connotation, while attract is more straightforward and practical.

Bewitch.wordDefinition:
Bewitch means to enchant or cast a supernatural spell on someone or something.

To summarize, attract is used in real life situations when someone is interested in someone or something, while bewitch is used in fictional or imaginary circumstances involving supernatural powers.

Charm.wordDefinition:
The words attract and charm both refer to making someone interested in you, but in slightly different ways. Attract means to draw someone towards you physically or emotionally, while charm means to captivate someone with your personality or behavior.

For example, someone might be attracted to another person because of their physical appearance, while someone might be charmed by another person's humor or kindness.

Attract is more commonly used to describe a physical or sexual attraction, while charm is more often used to describe a personality trait that makes someone likeable.

Draw.wordDefinition:
Draw means to pull something towards you or to create something out of your own abilities.

It can also mean to lead someone in a certain direction. For example, "The artist drew a beautiful picture", "The magician can draw a crowd with his performances", and "The map drew our attention to the shortcut".

Attract is used when seeking interest or attention, while draw refers to pulling something in a certain direction or creating something.

Entice.wordDefinition:
Entice refers to persuading or enticing someone to do something or go somewhere, often by offering them something they want.

For example, a restaurant might entice customers with a special discount or offer to attract them to eat there.

Attract refers to a natural draw or interest, while entice refers to an artificial stimulus or persuasion.

Fascinate.wordDefinition:
Attract means to draw or pull something towards you, while the word fascinate means to captivate or strongly interest someone.

Fascinate is applicable when you want to describe something that captivates or intrigues the mind or senses, for example, a captivating book can fascinate a reader.

Magnetize.wordDefinition:
Both words, attract and magnetize can mean to pull or draw something towards oneself.

However, attract is a broader term that can describe any kind of pull, while magnetize specifically refers to the magnetic force.

For example, a person might be attracted to someone's personality or appearance, but a magnet can only magnetize metal objects.

Attract can be used in a variety of situations and contexts, while magnetize is more specific to the science of magnets.

Seduce.wordDefinition:
The basic difference between attract and seduce is that attract means to draw someone towards you through your magnetism, charm, or beauty, while seduce means to persuade someone to do something through the use of flattering words, gifts, or actions that might seem inappropriate or unacceptable.

For example, if you are attractive in appearance, people will naturally be drawn towards you, whereas if you try to seduce someone, you might try to coax or persuade them to do something they might not be comfortable with.

Seduce is usually used in a more romantic context, where one person is trying to persuade another to engage in intimate behavior.

The key thing to remember is that while attraction is natural and healthy, seduction can be manipulative and harmful.

Tempt.wordDefinition:
Tempt means to try to persuade someone to do something by offering them something that they want but should not have.

It's often used in the context of temptation or seduction.

Both words are applicable in different situations. Attract is more commonly used to describe a natural draw, while tempt is often used in situations where there is a specific good or reward that people want, but it might not be good for them.

For instance, you might say that a musician attracted a large audience with their talent. Or you might say that someone was tempted to cheat on their exam because they didn't study enough.

quotes.Text: I have been in love, and it was a great feeling. It's when you are attracted to and feel affection for someone. You want to do things for that person. But only love isn't enough in a relationship - understanding and communication are very important aspects.
quotes.Title: Indian Athlete
quotes.Name: Yuvraj Singh

quotes.Text: My first big mission for UNICEF in Ethiopia was just to attract attention, before it was too late, to conditions which threatened the whole country. My role was to inform the world, to make sure that the people of Ethiopia were not forgotten.
quotes.Title: British Actress
quotes.Name: Audrey Hepburn

quotes.Text: It is by a wise economy of nature that those who suffer without change, and whom no one can help, become uninteresting. Yet so it may happen that those who need sympathy the most often attract it the least.
quotes.Title: British Philosopher
quotes.Name: F. H. Bradley

quotes.Text: I've always said, if you treat yourself like a queen, you'll attract a king.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Pepa

quotes.Text: I've always been very much attracted to a character that's actually free.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Jim Harrison

quotes.Text: A quiet personality sure isn't what you need to attract attention.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Bill Budge

quotes.Text: What I didn't know was I was deeply attracted to the big space.
quotes.Title: English Artist
quotes.Name: David Hockney

quotes.Text: In truth, Jesus did not, in his own time, attract much notice.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Jay Parini

quotes.Text: I'm attracted to playing characters that have flaws.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Sarah Shahi

quotes.Text: I am attracted to the dark side of life!
quotes.Title: Dutch Actress
quotes.Name: Famke Janssen
